title: Video Game History
q1: Identify key figures and designers, early games, milestones, and console wars
q2: Students will create a timeline of video game history, highlighting key figures, early games, significant milestones, and major events in the console wars. Each student will present a portion of the timeline to the class, explaining the importance of their chosen events and figures.
q3: In small groups, students will research specific eras or aspects of video game history. Each group will create a detailed presentation on their assigned topic and share their findings with the class. Students will provide feedback on each group’s presentation, focusing on the clarity and depth of the historical information presented.
q4: Students will submit their individual timelines as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their research findings and the feedback they received, along with any revisions made to their presentation.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the evolution of video games. Questions to prompt discussion: Who are some key figures or designers you’ve heard of in video game history? What are some of the earliest video games you know about? How do you think console wars have shaped the gaming industry?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to create a comprehensive timeline using a sample period in video game history. This could include: Showing a sample timeline with detailed events and well-organized content. Discussing the importance of each section: key figures, early games, significant milestones, and console wars. Highlighting examples of impactful moments and their significance in gaming history.
description: Introduction to Video Game History: Overview of the importance of studying video game history. How historical events and figures have shaped the current gaming landscape. Key Figures and Designers: Research and identify influential figures in video game history. Discuss their contributions and impact on the gaming industry. Early Games: Explore the development and significance of early video games. Discuss how these games influenced future game design and technology. Significant Milestones: Identify and analyze key milestones in the evolution of video games. Discuss the technological and cultural impact of these milestones. Console Wars: Understand the history and impact of major console wars (e.g., Sega vs. Nintendo, PlayStation vs. Xbox). Discuss how competition between console manufacturers has driven innovation and shaped the gaming market.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on video game history and influential figures. Game Developer for insights into significant milestones and industry developments. IGN for historical timelines and articles on console wars.

title: Game Ratings and Their History
q1: Each of the game ratings from eC - RP will be explored and memorized
q2: Students will research the ESRB rating system, its history, and the criteria for each rating. They will create a poster or infographic that details each rating, its meaning, and examples of games that fall under each category. This visual aid will help them and their classmates memorize the ratings and understand their significance.
q3: In pairs or small groups, students will quiz each other on the ESRB ratings and their meanings. They will use flashcards or an online quiz tool to reinforce their memory and understanding. Each group will also discuss why game ratings are important for consumers, parents, and developers.
q4: Students will submit their posters or infographics as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their discussion on the importance of game ratings.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the role of game ratings. Questions to prompt discussion: Why do you think game ratings are important? How do game ratings affect your choices as a player? Can you think of any controversies related to game ratings?
demo: The teacher will provide an overview of the ESRB rating system, including: The history and formation of the ESRB. Detailed explanations of each rating (eC, E, E10+, T, M, AO, RP). The criteria and content descriptors used to assign ratings. Examples of games for each rating category.
description: Introduction to the ESRB: Overview of the Entertainment Software Rating Board and its purpose. The historical context leading to the creation of the ESRB. Exploring Game Ratings: Detailed exploration of each ESRB rating from eC (Early Childhood) to RP (Rating Pending). Criteria and content descriptors associated with each rating. Memorization Techniques: Tips and techniques for memorizing the ESRB ratings and their meanings. Using visual aids, flashcards, and repetition for effective memorization. Importance of Game Ratings: Discussing the importance of game ratings for different stakeholders (players, parents, developers). Exploring real-world examples and controversies related to game ratings.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: ESRB Official Site for information on game ratings and the rating process. Common Sense Media for reviews and ratings of games from a parental perspective. Web Activities: Kahoot for creating interactive quizzes to test knowledge of ESRB ratings. Quizlet for flashcards and study games related to game ratings.

title: Impact and Evolution of Gaming
q1: Impact and evolution of gaming from social, economic, and other industries
q2: Students will create a timeline or infographic illustrating the key milestones in the evolution of gaming, highlighting significant social, economic, and technological impacts.
q3: In pairs, students will research a specific decade in gaming history and present their findings to the class. Each pair will focus on the societal, economic, and industry-related impacts of gaming during that time.
q4: Students will submit their timeline or infographic as a PDF file to Canvas. Additionally, they will submit a short reflection (250-300 words) on how gaming has evolved over the decades and its broader impact on society and industries.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite games and how they believe those games have impacted their lives or society. Questions to prompt discussion: What is your favorite game, and why? How do you think this game has influenced you or others? Have you noticed any economic or social impacts of gaming in your community?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the impact of a popular game, such as "Minecraft," by showing its evolution, economic impact, and influence on education and social interactions. Use multimedia resources like videos, charts, and articles to illustrate points.
description: Introduction to Gaming Evolution: Brief history of gaming from early arcade games to current trends. Key milestones and their significance. Social Impact: Discuss the influence of gaming on different age groups, communities, and social behaviors. Positive impacts (e.g., improved cognitive skills, social connections) and negative impacts (e.g., addiction, social isolation). Economic Impact: Analyze the growth of the gaming industry, including revenue statistics and job creation. Discuss the impact of major game releases on the economy. Influence on Other Industries: Explore how gaming technology has influenced advancements in other fields such as virtual reality in healthcare, simulation training in the military, and gamification in education.
content: Websites: The History of Gaming, Economic Impact of Gaming, Social Impact of Gaming - Web Activities: Create a Gaming Timeline, Infographic Tools, Articles and Videos: The Evolution of Video Games, The Economic Impact of the Video Game Industry, The Impact of Video Games on Society

title: Understand Game History, Ratings, Evolution
q1: Understanding of relevant history, ratings and gaming evolution

title: Game Strategy & Feedback
q1: Identify game strategies, player motivation, needed feedback, and duration
q2: Students will design a basic game concept, including the core strategy, player motivation elements, feedback mechanisms, and planned duration. This will be presented as a storyboard or flowchart.
q3: In small groups, students will analyze a popular game to identify its strategy, player motivation factors, feedback systems, and how the duration keeps players engaged. Each group will present their findings to the class.
q4: Students will submit their game concept storyboard or flowchart as a PDF file to Canvas. Additionally, each group will submit a summary (200-300 words) of their analysis of the popular game.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on different types of games they enjoy and what strategies they believe make these games engaging. Questions to prompt discussion: What game genres do you prefer and why? What strategies do these games use to keep you engaged? How do these games provide feedback to players?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the game "Tetris" to illustrate game strategy, player motivation, feedback, and duration. This will include: A brief playthrough of the game. Highlighting the strategy involved in fitting pieces together. Discussing how the game motivates players to improve their skills. Showing feedback through scores and levels. Explaining how the increasing difficulty affects game duration.
description: Introduction to Game Strategies: Overview of common game strategies in different genres (e.g., puzzle, strategy, RPG, action). Examples of successful games and their strategies. Understanding Player Motivation: Discuss intrinsic and extrinsic motivation. Elements that drive player engagement (e.g., challenge, reward, progression). Feedback Mechanisms in Games: Importance of feedback in maintaining player engagement. Types of feedback (e.g., visual, auditory, haptic). Examples from popular games. Determining Game Duration: Factors that influence appropriate game duration. Balancing game length to maintain interest without causing fatigue.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Game Design Strategies, Understanding Player Motivation, Feedback in Games. Web Activities: Storyboard That, Flowchart Maker, Articles and Videos: Game Design Strategies Explained, Player Motivation in Games, The Role of Feedback in Game Design

title: Game Control
q1: Understand design function, usable game controls, accessibility, and immersion
q2: Students will design a control scheme for a simple game concept, ensuring it incorporates usability, accessibility, and immersion. This will be presented as a diagram or detailed description.
q3: In pairs, students will evaluate the control scheme of a popular game, noting its strengths and weaknesses in terms of usability, accessibility, and immersion. Each pair will present their analysis to the class.
q4: Students will submit their control scheme design as a PDF file to Canvas. Additionally, they will submit a short analysis (200-300 words) of how their design meets the criteria of usability, accessibility, and immersion.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite game controls and what makes them effective. Questions to prompt discussion: What game has the best controls in your opinion and why? What makes a control scheme easy or difficult to use? Have you encountered any games with excellent accessibility features?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the control scheme of a well-known game, such as "Celeste," highlighting its design, usability, accessibility features, and how it contributes to immersion. This will include: A brief playthrough to showcase the controls. Discussing the design choices that make the controls effective. Highlighting any accessibility options. Explaining how the control scheme enhances the immersive experience.
description: Introduction to Game Control Design: Overview of control design principles. Importance of intuitive controls in player experience. Usable Game Controls: Characteristics of usable and intuitive controls. Examples from various games and genres. Accessibility in Game Controls: Importance of accessibility in game design. Features that enhance accessibility (e.g., remappable controls, alternative input methods). Control Design and Immersion: How well-designed controls contribute to a player’s sense of immersion. Balancing complexity and simplicity to maintain engagement without frustration.
content: Websites:Game Accessibility Guidelines, Usability in Game Design, Immersion and Game Controls - Web Activities: Create a Control Scheme Diagram, Accessibility Checker - Articles and Videos: Designing Intuitive Game Controls, Game Accessibility Features, Control Design and Immersion

title: Design Aesthetics
q1: Implementation of design aesthetics like world creation and four types of player views
q2: Students will create a basic concept for a game world, including environmental details and player views. This will be presented as a visual storyboard or concept art with annotations.
q3: In small groups, students will analyze a well-known game to identify its design aesthetics, world creation techniques, and player views. Each group will present their analysis to the class, focusing on how these elements contribute to the overall game experience.
q4: Students will submit their visual storyboard or concept art as a PDF file to Canvas. Additionally, they will submit a short reflection (200-300 words) on the design choices they made and how they enhance the game experience.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite game worlds and player views. Questions to prompt discussion: What game world do you find most immersive and why? Which player view do you prefer and how does it impact your gaming experience? Can you identify a game that uses multiple player views effectively?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the design aesthetics of a popular game, such as "The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild," highlighting its world creation and player views. This will include: A brief playthrough or walkthrough to showcase the game world and player views. Discussing the design choices that make the world immersive. Explaining the different types of player views used and their impact on gameplay.
description: Introduction to Design Aesthetics: Overview of design aesthetics in games. Importance of cohesive and engaging visual design. World Creation: Techniques for creating immersive game worlds. Examples of successful world designs in various games. Types of Player Views: First-person view: Immersion and personal experience. Third-person view: Character-focused and situational awareness. Top-down view: Strategic and overview perspective. Side-scrolling view: Classic gameplay and simplicity. Examples of games utilizing each view effectively.
content: Websites: ArtStation for game concept art and inspiration. Gamasutra for articles on game design aesthetics. Polycount for game art and design discussions. - Web Activities: Storyboard That for creating visual storyboards. Concept Art Tools for digital drawing and concept creation. - Articles and Videos: World Building in Games, Understanding Player Views, Designing Immersive Game Worlds

title: Interface Elements
q1: Exploration of interface elements including diegetic and non-diegetic design and functionality
q2: Students will design a user interface (UI) for a simple game concept, incorporating both diegetic and non-diegetic elements. This will be presented as a visual mockup or wireframe with annotations explaining the design choices.
q3: In pairs, students will analyze the UI of a popular game, identifying diegetic and non-diegetic elements and discussing their functionality and impact on the player experience. Each pair will present their findings to the class.
q4: Students will submit their UI mockup or wireframe as a PDF file to Canvas. Additionally, they will submit a short analysis (200-300 words) on the effectiveness of their design in enhancing user experience and gameplay.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the importance of UI in games. Questions to prompt discussion: What game UIs do you find most effective and why? Can you think of examples of diegetic and non-diegetic elements in games you’ve played? How do these elements impact your gameplay experience?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the UI of a well-known game, such as "Dead Space," highlighting its diegetic and non-diegetic elements. This will include: A brief playthrough or walkthrough to showcase the UI. Discussing the design choices that make the UI effective. Explaining the difference between diegetic and non-diegetic elements and their roles in the game.
description: Introduction to Interface Elements: Overview of interface elements in games. Importance of a well-designed UI for player experience. Diegetic Interface Elements: Definition and examples (e.g., in-game maps, health indicators integrated into the game world). Benefits and challenges of diegetic elements. Non-Diegetic Interface Elements: Definition and examples (e.g., HUDs, menus, scoreboards). Benefits and challenges of non-diegetic elements. Designing Effective UI: Principles of effective UI design. Balancing diegetic and non-diegetic elements to enhance gameplay and immersion.
content: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on UI design in games. UX Design for principles of user experience design. Game UI Database for examples of game UIs. Web Activities: Wireframe Tools for creating UI mockups. UI Design Software for designing interactive interfaces. Articles and Videos: Understanding Diegetic and Non-Diegetic UI, UI Design in Games,  Effective Game UI Design Principles

title: Understand Game Design, View and Interface
q1: Understanding of game functionality and feedback as well as control, views and interface elements

title: Game Platforms Introduction
q1: Identify game platforms like console, desktop/laptop, and mobile
q2: Students will create a comparison chart that details the features, advantages, and disadvantages of console, desktop/laptop, and mobile gaming platforms. This chart will include examples of popular games for each platform and how their design is influenced by the platform's characteristics.
q3: In small groups, students will select one game platform and research a popular game developed for that platform. They will present their findings, focusing on how the platform's features influence the game's design, controls, and player experience.
q4: Students will submit their comparison chart as a PDF file to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their presentation on the selected game platform and game.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the different game platforms they use. Questions to prompt discussion: Which game platform do you use most frequently and why? What do you think are the main differences between playing games on a console, desktop/laptop, and mobile? Have you noticed any differences in game design or controls across these platforms?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the differences between game platforms using specific examples. This could include: Showing gameplay footage from a console game, a desktop/laptop game, and a mobile game. Discussing the unique features of each platform, such as control schemes, graphics capabilities, and user interfaces. Highlighting how these features impact game design and player experience.
description: Introduction to Game Platforms: Overview of the main game platforms: console, desktop/laptop, and mobile. Brief history and evolution of each platform. Console Gaming: Characteristics of console gaming (e.g., dedicated hardware, standardized controls). Examples of popular console games and how they utilize platform features. Desktop/Laptop Gaming: Characteristics of desktop/laptop gaming (e.g., customizable hardware, diverse control options). Examples of popular desktop/laptop games and how they utilize platform features. Mobile Gaming: Characteristics of mobile gaming (e.g., touch controls, portability, varying screen sizes). Examples of popular mobile games and how they utilize platform features.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game development for different platforms. IGN for reviews and analysis of games on various platforms. Game Developer for insights into platform-specific game development. Web Activities: Platform Comparison Chart Template for creating comparison charts. Game Development Forums for discussions on platform-specific development. Articles and Videos: Understanding Game Platforms - video explaining different game platforms. Console vs. PC Gaming - video comparison of console and PC gaming. Mobile Game Development - video on the unique aspects of mobile game development.

title: Strengths/Weaknesses in Platforms
q1: Identify platform considerations like display, hardware performance, input, portability and affordability
q2: Students will create a detailed comparison table that evaluates the strengths and weaknesses of console, desktop/laptop, and mobile platforms based on display, hardware performance, input methods, portability, and affordability. This table will include specific examples and data to support their evaluations.
q3: In small groups, students will select one game platform and investigate a specific game developed for that platform. They will analyze how the platform's strengths and weaknesses influenced the game's design and overall player experience. Each group will present their findings to the class.
q4: Students will submit their comparison table as a PDF file to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their analysis and presentation on the selected game and platform.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the advantages and disadvantages they’ve noticed with different game platforms. Questions to prompt discussion: What are the main strengths of your preferred gaming platform? What are some weaknesses or limitations you’ve encountered with this platform? How do these strengths and weaknesses affect your gaming experience?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the strengths and weaknesses of different game platforms using specific examples. This could include: Showing side-by-side comparisons of the same game on different platforms (e.g., "Fortnite" on console, desktop, and mobile). Discussing the differences in display quality, hardware performance, input methods, portability, and affordability. Highlighting how these differences impact gameplay and player experience.
description: Introduction to Platform Considerations: Overview of key factors: display, hardware performance, input methods, portability, and affordability. Importance of considering these factors in game development and player experience. Console Gaming: Strengths: Standardized hardware, optimized performance, dedicated gaming controls. Weaknesses: Less customizable, generally less portable, can be expensive. Desktop/Laptop Gaming: Strengths: Customizable hardware, high performance potential, variety of input methods. Weaknesses: Can be expensive, less portable, requires maintenance. Mobile Gaming: Strengths: Highly portable, affordable, intuitive touch controls. Weaknesses: Limited hardware performance, smaller displays, variable input quality.

title: Impact of Cloud Computing on Game Design
q1: Understand the impact cloud resources for distribution, updates, dependency on internet, and hardware dependency
q2: Students will create a detailed report or presentation that examines the impact of cloud computing on game design. This will include sections on distribution, updates, internet dependency, and hardware dependency, supported by specific examples from the gaming industry.
q3: In small groups, students will select a cloud-based game or service (e.g., Google Stadia, Xbox Cloud Gaming) and analyze how cloud computing has influenced its design and user experience. Each group will present their findings to the class.
q4: Students will submit their report or presentation as a PDF file to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their analysis and presentation on the selected cloud-based game or service.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their experiences with cloud-based games or services. Questions to prompt discussion: Have you played any games that rely on cloud computing? What was your experience like? What do you think are the main benefits of cloud gaming? What potential challenges or drawbacks have you noticed with cloud-based games?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the impact of cloud computing on game design using specific examples. This could include: Showing gameplay footage or a demo of a cloud-based game (e.g., "Fortnite" with cloud saves, "Cyberpunk 2077" on Google Stadia). Discussing how cloud resources are used for game distribution and updates. Highlighting the dependency on internet connectivity for cloud gaming. Explaining how cloud computing can reduce hardware dependency and enhance accessibility.
description: Introduction to Cloud Computing in Gaming: Overview of cloud computing and its relevance to the gaming industry. Importance of cloud resources in modern game design and distribution. Cloud-Based Game Distribution: How cloud computing facilitates game distribution. Benefits and challenges of distributing games via the cloud. Automatic Updates and Patches: Role of cloud computing in delivering updates and patches. Impact on game maintenance and user experience. Internet Dependency: Importance of a stable internet connection for cloud gaming. Potential issues and solutions for internet dependency. Hardware Dependency: How cloud computing can reduce the need for high-end hardware. Examples of cloud gaming services that leverage this advantage.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on cloud gaming and its impact. IGN for reviews and comparisons of cloud gaming services. Game Developer for insights into cloud computing in game development. Web Activities: Cloud Gaming Forum for discussions on cloud gaming experiences and technologies. Comparison Tools for creating detailed reports and presentations.

title: Distribution Channels (Disk, Download, Stream)
q1: Identify distribution channels like physical media, download, Steam, Epic, Apple, Microsoft etc.
q2: Students will create a comparison chart that evaluates various game distribution channels. The chart will include physical media, digital downloads, and streaming services, focusing on specific platforms like Steam, Epic Games Store, Apple App Store, and Microsoft Store. Each channel should be evaluated based on factors such as accessibility, cost, storage requirements, and user experience.
q3: In small groups, students will select one distribution channel or platform and research its impact on the game market. They will analyze its strengths, weaknesses, and unique features. Each group will present their findings to the class, including examples of games distributed through their chosen channel.
q4: Students will submit their comparison chart as a PDF file to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their analysis and presentation on the selected distribution channel or platform.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the various ways they acquire games. Questions to prompt discussion: How do you usually get new games (physical copies, downloads, streaming)? Which distribution channel do you prefer and why? What do you think are the main benefits and drawbacks of each distribution method?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the differences between game distribution channels using specific examples. This could include: Showing gameplay or trailers of games available through different channels (e.g., physical copy of "The Legend of Zelda," digital download of "Cyberpunk 2077," streamed game on Google Stadia). Discussing how each distribution channel works and its impact on game accessibility and user experience. Highlighting the pros and cons of each distribution method.
description: Introduction to Distribution Channels: Overview of different game distribution channels: physical media, digital downloads, and streaming services. Importance of distribution channels in the gaming industry. Physical Media: Characteristics and examples of physical media distribution (e.g., game disks, cartridges). Benefits (e.g., ownership, collectible value) and drawbacks (e.g., storage space, physical damage). Digital Downloads:Characteristics and examples of digital download platforms (e.g., Steam, Epic Games Store). Benefits (e.g., instant access, convenience) and drawbacks (e.g., storage requirements, DRM). Streaming Services: Characteristics and examples of game streaming services (e.g., Google Stadia, Xbox Cloud Gaming). Benefits (e.g., no need for high-end hardware, portability) and drawbacks (e.g., internet dependency, latency). Platform-Specific Analysis: Steam: Large library, community features, sales. Epic Games Store: Exclusive titles, free games, developer-friendly revenue model. Apple App Store: Mobile games, strict quality control, integrated with iOS devices. Microsoft Store: Integration with Xbox, Game Pass, cross-platform play.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game distribution trends. IGN for reviews and analysis of different game distribution platforms. Game Developer for insights into the game distribution market. Web Activities: Comparison Chart Tool for creating detailed comparison charts. Game Distribution Forums for discussions on distribution strategies.

title: Understand Platforms, Mobile, and Distribution
q1: Describe consoles, platforms, mobile, and distribution methods

title: Term 1 Concept Review and Test
q1: Test on Strands 1-3

title: Game Genres (Action, Role, Sim, Strategy, Hybrid)
q1: Understand game genres like action, adventure, role play, simulation, strategy and many forms of hybrids
q2: Students will create a detailed presentation that explains each game genre, providing examples and highlighting key characteristics. The presentation will also include a section on hybrid genres, illustrating how elements from different genres can be combined to create new gaming experiences.
q3: In small groups, students will select a game from one of the specified genres and analyze its core elements, mechanics, and player experience. Each group will present their findings to the class, explaining how the game fits into its genre and discussing any hybrid elements.
q4: Students will submit their presentations as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their analysis and presentation on the selected game and genre.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite games and the genres they belong to. Questions to prompt discussion: What is your favorite game and what genre does it belong to? What features or mechanics define this genre? Have you played any games that combine elements from multiple genres?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the characteristics of different game genres using specific examples. This could include: Showing gameplay footage from different genres (e.g., action game "Call of Duty," role-playing game "The Witcher 3," simulation game "The Sims," strategy game "Civilization VI"). Discussing the core elements and mechanics that define each genre. Highlighting examples of hybrid genres and how they combine elements from multiple genres (e.g., "Fortnite" combining action and building simulation).
description: Introduction to Game Genres: Overview of the importance of game genres in the gaming industry. How genres help players identify the type of gameplay experience they can expect. Action Games: Characteristics: fast-paced gameplay, reflex-based mechanics, emphasis on combat. Examples: "Call of Duty," "Devil May Cry," "DOOM." Role-Playing Games (RPGs): Characteristics: story-driven, character development, quest-based gameplay. Examples: "The Witcher 3," "Final Fantasy VII," "Skyrim." Simulation Games: Characteristics: focus on simulating real-life activities, detailed mechanics. Examples: "The Sims," "SimCity," "Flight Simulator." Strategy Games: Characteristics: tactical gameplay, resource management, long-term planning. Examples: "Civilization VI," "StarCraft," "XCOM." Adventure Games: Characteristics: narrative-driven, puzzle-solving, exploration.Examples: "The Legend of Zelda," "Uncharted," "Monkey Island." Hybrid Genres: Characteristics: combination of elements from multiple genres to create unique gameplay experiences. Examples: "Fortnite" (action and building), "Stardew Valley" (simulation and RPG), "Dark Souls" (action and RPG).
content: Links and Resources:Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game design and genre analysis. IGN for reviews and genre classifications of various games. Game Developer for insights into game mechanics and genre trends. Web Activities: Presentation Tool for creating detailed presentations. Gaming Forums for discussions on favorite genres and game recommendations.

title: Game Types (Single, 2 Player, Coop, Comp, Team)
q1: Identify game types like single player, two player, multi competitive, multi cooperative, and team based
q2: Students will create a detailed chart that categorizes various games into the specified types. The chart will include examples for each type, highlighting key characteristics and the player experience. Each game type section should include an analysis of the design considerations unique to that type.
q3: In small groups, students will select a game from one of the specified types and analyze its core elements, mechanics, and player interactions. Each group will present their findings to the class, explaining how the game fits into its type and discussing any unique design challenges.
q4: Students will submit their charts as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their analysis and presentation on the selected game and game type.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite types of games and why they enjoy them. Questions to prompt discussion: What type of game do you prefer to play (single player, multiplayer, etc.) and why? What are the main differences in your experience when playing different types of games? Have you noticed any specific challenges or advantages associated with each game type?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the characteristics of different game types using specific examples. This could include: Showing gameplay footage from different game types (e.g., single player game "The Witcher 3," two-player game "Mario Kart," multiplayer competitive game "Overwatch," multiplayer cooperative game "Left 4 Dead," team-based game "League of Legends"). Discussing the core elements and mechanics that define each game type. Highlighting examples of design considerations and challenges unique to each game type.
description: Introduction to Game Types: Overview of the importance of game types in the gaming industry. How game types influence player experience and game design. Single Player Games: Characteristics: story-driven, solo experience, often with complex narratives. Examples: "The Witcher 3," "Skyrim," "Hollow Knight." Two Player Games: Characteristics: designed for two players, can be competitive or cooperative. Examples: "Mario Kart," "Portal 2," "Streets of Rage 4." Multiplayer Competitive Games: Characteristics: players compete against each other, focus on skill and strategy. Examples: "Overwatch," "Fortnite," "Call of Duty." Multiplayer Cooperative Games: Characteristics: players work together to achieve common goals, focus on teamwork. Examples: "Left 4 Dead," "Borderlands," "Destiny." Team-Based Games: Characteristics: organized teams compete or cooperate, often in larger groups. Examples: "League of Legends," "Dota 2," "Rainbow Six Siege."
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game design and player experience. IGN for reviews and genre classifications of various games. Game Developer for insights into game mechanics and design. Web Activities: Chart Tool for creating detailed charts. Gaming Forums for discussions on favorite game types and recommendations.

title: Understand Genres and Game Types
q1: Identify and understand genres and game types

title: Concept Development (Pitch SB Plan, Cost, Time)
q1: Understanding of development concepts like plan, cost and time with a pitch document, storyboard and sketches of characters and envirnment
q2: Students will develop a game concept and create a comprehensive pitch document. This document will include a high-level plan, cost estimate, timeline, storyboard, and sketches of characters and environments. Each student will present their pitch to the class.
q3: In small groups, students will collaborate to refine their pitch documents. They will review each other's work, provide constructive feedback, and discuss ways to improve their concepts. Each group will then present a refined pitch to the class for further discussion and critique.
q4: Students will submit their pitch documents as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their final presentation.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite game concepts and what makes them compelling. Questions to prompt discussion: What game concept do you find most interesting and why? What elements do you think are essential in a compelling game pitch? How do you think planning, cost, and time management impact game development?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to create an effective pitch document using a sample game concept. This could include: Showing a sample pitch document with a clear structure and detailed content. Discussing the importance of each section: plan, cost estimate, timeline, storyboard, and sketches. Highlighting examples of good character and environment sketches and how they contribute to the overall concept.
description: Introduction to Concept Development: Overview of the importance of concept development in game design. How planning, budgeting, and time management are critical to the success of a game project. Creating a Pitch Document: Elements of a pitch document: title, high-level plan, cost estimate, timeline, storyboard, sketches. How to structure and format a pitch document for clarity and impact. Storyboarding: Importance of storyboarding in visualizing the game concept. Techniques for creating effective storyboards. Sketching Characters and Environments: Basic principles of character and environment design. Tips for creating compelling and visually appealing sketches. Planning, Cost, and Time Management: Developing a high-level plan that outlines the key milestones and deliverables. Estimating costs and budgeting for a game project. Creating a timeline that allocates time effectively across different phases of development.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game design and development. Concept Art World for inspiration and tutorials on character and environment sketches. Game Developer for insights into game development processes. Web Activities: Storyboard That for creating detailed storyboards. Sketch.io for online sketching tools.

title: Pre-Production (Game Design Document)
q1: Brainstorm production plan design document list
q2: Students will create a Game Design Document for a hypothetical game. This document will include sections on the game concept, gameplay mechanics, storyline, characters, environments, art style, audio, and a high-level production plan. Each student will present their GDD to the class, explaining their design choices and development strategy.
q3: In small groups, students will review each other's Game Design Documents, providing constructive feedback and suggestions for improvement. Each group will then refine their documents based on the feedback received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their Game Design Documents as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their final document.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on their favorite games and what makes the design compelling. Questions to prompt discussion: What elements of game design do you find most important and why? Have you ever thought about the planning and documentation that goes into game development? How do you think a well-structured GDD can impact the success of a game?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to create a comprehensive Game Design Document using a sample game concept. This could include: Showing a sample GDD with detailed sections and well-organized content. Discussing the importance of each section: concept, mechanics, storyline, characters, environments, art style, audio, production plan. Highlighting examples of effective design choices and clear documentation.
description: Introduction to Game Design Documents: Overview of the purpose and importance of a GDD in game development. How a GDD helps in organizing ideas and planning the production process. Components of a Game Design Document: Game Concept: Brief overview of the game’s idea, genre, and target audience. Gameplay Mechanics: Detailed description of game rules, controls, objectives, and core gameplay loops. Storyline: Summary of the game’s plot, including main story arcs, key events, and character development. Characters: Descriptions of main characters, their roles, backstories, and relationships. Environments: Detailed descriptions of game settings, including visual style and key locations. Art Style: Outline of the visual aesthetic, including concept art and style guides. Audio: Overview of the game’s audio design, including music, sound effects, and voice acting. Production Plan: High-level timeline, budget estimates, and team roles. Brainstorming and Planning: Techniques for brainstorming game ideas and organizing thoughts. Tips for planning a production strategy and setting realistic goals.
content: Links and Resources:Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game design and documentation. Game Design Document Templates for downloadable GDD templates. Game Developer for insights into game development processes. Web Activities: Milanote for creating visual and organized Game Design Documents. Trello for planning and organizing production plans.

title: Repo Planning Docs
q1: Preparation of game plan document (see list in standards)
q2: Students will create a comprehensive game plan document for a hypothetical game. The document will include sections such as game overview, objectives, gameplay mechanics, technical specifications, art and audio assets, team roles, timeline, and budget. Each student will present their game plan to the class, explaining their design choices and development strategy.
q3: In small groups, students will review each other’s game plan documents, providing constructive feedback and suggestions for improvement. Each group will then refine their documents based on the feedback received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their game plan documents as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their final document.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on what they think are the most important elements of a game plan. Questions to prompt discussion: What key elements do you think should be included in a game plan document? How do you think a well-prepared game plan can impact the success of a game project? What challenges do you anticipate when creating a comprehensive game plan?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to create a comprehensive game plan document using a sample game concept. This could include: Showing a sample game plan document with detailed sections and well-organized content. Discussing the importance of each section: game overview, objectives, gameplay mechanics, technical specifications, art and audio assets, team roles, timeline, budget. Highlighting examples of effective planning and clear documentation.
description: Introduction to Game Plan Documents: Overview of the purpose and importance of a game plan document in game development. How a game plan document helps in organizing ideas and planning the development process. Components of a Game Plan Document: Game Overview: Brief description of the game’s idea, genre, and target audience. Objectives: Goals and objectives of the game, including learning outcomes if applicable. Gameplay Mechanics: Detailed description of game rules, controls, objectives, and core gameplay loops. Technical Specifications: Hardware and software requirements, development tools, and platforms. Art and Audio Assets: Descriptions of the visual and audio elements, including concept art and sound design. Team Roles: Roles and responsibilities of team members involved in the project. Timeline: High-level timeline with milestones and deliverables. Budget: Estimated costs and budgeting for the game project. Brainstorming and Planning: Techniques for brainstorming game ideas and organizing thoughts. Tips for planning a development strategy and setting realistic goals.
content: Links and Resources:Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game design and documentation. Game Design Document Templates for downloadable game plan templates. Game Developer for insights into game development processes. Web Activities: Milanote for creating visual and organized game plan documents. Trello for planning and organizing development plans.

title: Production (Create Assets and Logic etc.)
q1: Production gantt chart
q2: Students will create a Gantt chart for the production phase of a hypothetical game project. This chart will include tasks related to asset creation (art, sound, etc.), game logic implementation (coding, scripting, etc.), and key milestones. Each student will present their Gantt chart to the class, explaining their production plan and timeline.
q3: In small groups, students will review each other’s Gantt charts, providing constructive feedback and suggestions for improvement. Each group will then refine their charts based on the feedback received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their Gantt charts as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their final chart.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the challenges and important aspects of the production phase in game development. Questions to prompt discussion: What do you think are the most important tasks during the production phase of game development? How do you think a Gantt chart can help manage and organize the production process? What are some potential challenges you foresee in creating and following a production schedule?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to create a comprehensive Gantt chart using a sample game project. This could include: Showing a sample Gantt chart with detailed tasks and well-organized content. Discussing the importance of each section: asset creation, game logic implementation, milestones, and deliverables. Highlighting examples of effective scheduling and tracking of progress.
description: Introduction to Production Phase: Overview of the production phase in game development. Importance of asset creation and game logic implementation. Creating a Gantt Chart: What is a Gantt chart and its role in project management. Components of a Gantt chart: tasks, timelines, milestones, and dependencies. Asset Creation: Key tasks involved in creating game assets such as art, sound, and animation. Tips for organizing and managing asset creation tasks. Game Logic Implementation: Key tasks involved in implementing game logic such as coding and scripting. Tips for organizing and managing game logic tasks. Scheduling and Tracking: Techniques for scheduling tasks and setting realistic deadlines. Tips for tracking progress and making adjustments to the schedule.
content: Links and Resources:Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game development and project management. Smartsheet for Gantt chart templates and project management tools. Game Developer for insights into game development processes. Web Activities: Trello for planning and organizing development tasks. GanttPRO for creating and managing Gantt charts online.

title: Repo Assets
q1: Pruduction of assets and game logic etc.
q2: Students will produce a set of game assets (e.g., character sprites, background music, sound effects) and implement basic game logic (e.g., player movement, collision detection) for a simple game. They will organize these assets and code in a structured repository. Each student will present their repository, explaining their asset creation and implementation process.
q3: In small groups, students will review each other’s repositories, providing constructive feedback on the organization, quality, and implementation of assets and game logic. Each group will refine their repositories based on the feedback received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their repository (including assets and game logic) as a compressed ZIP file to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their final repository.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the creation and organization of game assets and logic. Questions to prompt discussion: What types of assets are important for a game, and why? How can organizing assets in a repository help in game development? What challenges might you face when creating and implementing game logic?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the production and organization of game assets and logic using a sample project. This could include: Creating a simple character sprite, background music, and sound effects. Implementing basic game logic such as player movement and collision detection. Organizing these assets and scripts in a structured repository. Discussing best practices for documentation and version control.
description: Introduction to Game Assets and Logic: Overview of different types of game assets (art, audio, etc.) and their importance. Explanation of game logic and its role in game functionality. Creating Game Assets: Techniques for creating high-quality art assets (e.g., character sprites, backgrounds). Methods for producing and editing audio assets (e.g., sound effects, background music). Implementing Game Logic: Basic coding principles for game development. Implementing simple game mechanics (e.g., player movement, collision detection). Organizing and Managing Assets: Importance of organizing assets in a repository. Best practices for documentation and version control. Feedback and Refinement: Techniques for providing and receiving constructive feedback. Importance of refining assets and logic based on feedback.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Unity Learn for tutorials on creating and implementing game assets and logic. Krita for creating and editing art assets. Audacity for producing and editing audio assets. Web Activities: GitHub for version control and repository management. Scratch for simple game logic implementation and asset creation.

title: Post-Production (Testing and Relese)
q1: Post production concepts understood: alpha and beta testing, game release and maintenance
q2: Students will create a testing plan for a hypothetical game, including detailed steps for both alpha and beta testing. They will also outline a release strategy and a maintenance plan for post-release. Each student will present their testing and release plan to the class, explaining their approach and the rationale behind their decisions.
q3: In small groups, students will review and provide feedback on each other’s testing and release plans. Each group will refine their plans based on the feedback received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their testing and release plans as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their final plans.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the importance of testing and proper release strategies in game development. Questions to prompt discussion: What do you think are the key differences between alpha and beta testing? Why is it important to have a detailed plan for testing and releasing a game? What challenges might you face during the post-production phase?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to create a comprehensive testing and release plan using a sample game project. This could include: Outlining the steps and criteria for alpha and beta testing. Discussing the importance of collecting and acting on feedback during testing phases. Creating a timeline for game release, including marketing strategies and post-release maintenance plans.
description: Introduction to Post-Production: Overview of the post-production phase in game development. Importance of testing, game release, and maintenance. Alpha and Beta Testing: Definitions and purposes of alpha and beta testing. Key steps and best practices for conducting effective testing phases. Techniques for collecting and analyzing feedback from testers. Game Release Strategy: Steps involved in preparing for a game release. Importance of marketing and promotion during the release phase. Planning a release timeline and coordinating with various platforms. Post-Release Maintenance: Strategies for maintaining and updating a game after release. Importance of addressing bugs, releasing patches, and adding new content. Engaging with the player community for ongoing feedback and improvements. Feedback and Refinement: Techniques for providing and receiving constructive feedback. Importance of refining testing and release plans based on feedback.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on game testing and release strategies. Game Developer for insights into post-production processes. Unity Learn for tutorials on testing and releasing games. Web Activities: Trello for planning and organizing testing phases and release timelines. Bugzilla for tracking and managing bugs during testing.

title: Repo Project Finalization
q1: Alpha testing.
q2: Students will conduct alpha testing for their game project stored in a GitHub repository. They will create a plan for alpha testing, execute the testing process, and document the feedback received. Each student will present their testing process and findings to the class.
q3: In small groups, students will review each other's alpha testing plans and provide feedback. Each group will refine their testing plans based on the feedback received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their alpha testing plan, the documented feedback, and a summary of the findings as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received and how they incorporated it into their testing process.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the role of alpha testing in game development. Questions to prompt discussion: What is the purpose of alpha testing in game development? How can GitHub repositories help manage and conduct alpha testing? What challenges might arise during the alpha testing phase?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the process of setting up and conducting alpha testing using a GitHub repository. This could include: Creating a detailed alpha testing plan. Using GitHub to manage the alpha testing process, including creating issues and tracking feedback. Demonstrating how to collect and analyze feedback from testers.
description: Introduction to Alpha Testing: Overview of alpha testing and its importance in game development. Key objectives and outcomes of the alpha testing phase. Setting Up a GitHub Repository: Steps for creating and managing a GitHub repository for a game project. Best practices for organizing files and maintaining version control. Creating an Alpha Testing Plan: Detailed steps for planning and conducting alpha testing. Identifying key areas to test and setting up testing criteria. Managing the Testing Process: Using GitHub to create issues and track testing feedback. Techniques for communicating with testers and managing their feedback. Analyzing Feedback: Methods for collecting, categorizing, and analyzing feedback from alpha testers. Using feedback to make improvements and prepare for beta testing.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: GitHub Guides for tutorials on using GitHub effectively. Gamasutra for articles on alpha testing and feedback management. Web Activities: GitHub for managing repositories and tracking issues. Trello for organizing and managing testing tasks and feedback.

title: Project Peer Evaluation
q1: Beta testing and game release.
q2: Students will conduct beta testing for their peers' game projects and participate in peer evaluations. They will provide detailed feedback on the functionality, gameplay, and overall experience of the game. Each student will also create a release plan for their own game, outlining the steps necessary for a successful launch.
q3: In small groups, students will review each other's feedback and release plans, providing suggestions for improvement. Each group will refine their feedback and release plans based on the input received and discuss the changes in a follow-up session.
q4: Students will submit their beta testing feedback and release plan as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of the feedback they received on their plans and how they incorporated it into their final versions.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the role of beta testing and the steps involved in releasing a game. Questions to prompt discussion: How does beta testing differ from alpha testing, and why is it important? What are the key elements of a successful game release plan? What challenges might arise during the beta testing and release phases?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate the process of conducting beta testing and preparing for a game release using a sample project. This could include: Creating a detailed beta testing plan and executing tests. Using feedback from beta testers to improve the game. Outlining the steps involved in creating a release plan, including marketing and distribution strategies.
description: Introduction to Beta Testing: Overview of beta testing and its importance in game development. Key objectives and outcomes of the beta testing phase. Conducting Peer Evaluations: Techniques for providing constructive feedback on gameplay, functionality, and user experience. Best practices for receiving and incorporating feedback from peers. Preparing for Game Release: Steps involved in preparing a game for release, including final testing and bug fixing. Importance of marketing, promotion, and distribution strategies. Creating a timeline and checklist for a successful game launch. Managing the Release Process: Techniques for managing the release process, including coordination with platforms and distributors. Strategies for engaging with the player community post-release. Planning for post-release maintenance and updates.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Gamasutra for articles on beta testing and game release strategies. Game Developer for insights into peer evaluations and feedback. Web Activities: GitHub for managing repositories and tracking issues during beta testing. Trello for organizing and managing release tasks and timelines.

title: Production Cycle, Planning and Testing
q1: Implementation of project in pre, production and post processes

title: Career Awareness
q1: Career awareness with interest and ability in conjunction with actual job titles and current/future opportunities.
q2: Students will research different careers in game development and create a presentation on a specific job role they find interesting. They will explore job responsibilities, required skills, and potential career paths. Additionally, students will conduct informational interviews or watch interviews with professionals in the industry to gain deeper insights.
q3: In small groups, students will share their presentations and discuss the various career paths they have researched. Each group will create a mind map that highlights the connections between different job roles, skills required, and potential career advancement opportunities.
q4: Students will submit their presentation files and a summary of their informational interview or professional interview video as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit their mind map summarizing the career paths discussed.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the importance of career awareness in game development. Questions to prompt discussion: Why is it important to understand the different career paths in game development? What skills and interests do you have that align with careers in game development? How can researching careers help you plan your future in the industry?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to research career paths in game development, using specific job titles as examples. This could include: An overview of various job roles in game development (e.g., game designer, programmer, artist, sound designer, QA tester). Highlighting key responsibilities and required skills for each role. Discussing current and future trends in the job market for game development.
description: Introduction to Game Development Careers: Overview of the game development industry and its various career opportunities. Importance of aligning personal interests and abilities with career choices. Researching Job Roles: Techniques for researching different job roles in game development. Using resources such as job boards, company websites, and professional networks to find information. Informational Interviews: How to conduct informational interviews with professionals in the industry. Preparing questions and effectively gathering insights from interviews. Current and Future Opportunities: Discussing current job market trends and future opportunities in game development. Understanding how technological advancements and industry changes impact career opportunities.
content: Links and Resources:Websites: Game Developer for articles on careers and industry trends. Indeed for job listings and descriptions in game development. Web Activities: LinkedIn for networking and connecting with professionals in the game development industry. Glassdoor for company reviews, salary information, and career advice.

title: Educational Pursuits
q1: Educaiton pursuits that match interests and abilities.
q2: Students will research educational programs, certifications, and courses that are relevant to game development. They will create a detailed educational plan that includes potential schools, programs, and courses they might pursue. Additionally, students will reflect on how these educational opportunities align with their career goals and personal interests.
q3: In small groups, students will share their educational plans and provide feedback on each other’s choices. Each group will discuss the pros and cons of different educational paths and compile a resource list of recommended programs and courses.
q4: Students will submit their educational plans as PDF files to Canvas. Each group will also submit a summary (200-300 words) of their discussion and the compiled resource list.
starter: Begin with a student-led discussion on the importance of choosing the right educational path in game development. Questions to prompt discussion: What are some key factors to consider when selecting an educational program for game development? How do your interests and abilities influence your choice of academic paths? What resources can help you find the best educational opportunities in game development?
demo: The teacher will demonstrate how to research and evaluate educational programs in game development. This could include: An overview of different types of educational opportunities (e.g., degree programs, certifications, online courses). Demonstrating how to find and compare programs using resources like college websites, educational portals, and reviews. Discussing the importance of accreditation, faculty expertise, and industry connections in selecting a program.
description: Introduction to Educational Pathways: Overview of various educational options available for aspiring game developers. Importance of aligning educational pursuits with career goals and personal interests. Researching Programs and Courses: Techniques for researching and evaluating educational programs and courses. Using resources such as college websites, educational portals, and professional networks to find information. Creating an Educational Plan: Steps to create a detailed educational plan, including selecting schools, programs, and courses. Considering factors such as program length, cost, location, and curriculum focus. Continuous Learning and Development: Importance of continuous learning and professional development in the game development industry. Exploring additional learning opportunities such as workshops, seminars, and industry conferences.
content: Links and Resources: Websites: Game Design Schools for information on top game design schools and programs. Coursera for online courses and certifications in game development and related fields. Web Activities: LinkedIn Learning for online courses and professional development resources. Udemy for affordable online courses on various aspects of game development.

title: Game Dev Jobs, Trends, and Ed Requirements
q1: Understand careers related to gaming industry and paths to educate and work in the field

title: State Test Review
q1: Test prep on strands 4-6

title: State Certification Test
q1: State certification exam on all strands.
